comments.author: jeewhiz67

comments.text:
+Holymakinaw
In the OP, I merely noted a fact that is often denounced as racist 
propaganda - Young black men ARE more likely to act violently. You 
childishly call me a moron because, in your opinion, this condition is 
clearly the result of the crimogenic effect of structural disadvantages 
(poverty, etc). If this is a foregone conclusion, then why has there been 
decades of research on this and the debate persists? In fact, the study 
that you submit is extremely involved and quite exhaustive but the authors 
are still compelled to caveat their findings by the admission that, *"further 
research on this topic is needed..."*

Furthermore, the authors justifiably note problems with their study:
 - Errors/problems of using OLS as a mathematical model for data analysis 
(outliers, non-linear data.
 - Problem of restricted distributions - McNulty (2001)
 - Study did not examine the relationship between race-specific poverty and 
race-specific violent crime in racially mixed neighborhoods.
 - Study was limited to just one city and compromised by estimation issues 
related to sample size.

Really_you_ should have read _your_source material. You frantically Googled 
"Race and Poverty") and found a study that is probably not even peer 
reviewed yet and authored by individuals from a 3rd rate University, 
Villanova.
This paper does NOT conclusively support the conclusion that you are so 
desperately trying to make - poverty’s criminogenic effect as racially 
invariant.
It only poses the question: IS POVERTY’S DETRIMENTAL EFFECT RACE-SPECIFIC?

This question has been researched for decades and is attended by opposing 
views that inner-city crime rates are predicated by structural disadvantage 
(social disorganization theory) Vs moral poverty.

Frankly, I don't know why there's more violent crime in poor black areas 
but it must be multi-factorial. Poverty is certainly one factor. You do not 
know the answer and neither, apparently, does the academic community.
comments.author: keereekee
